questions.question: What happens to the coherence time when the velocity of the user is doubled?

explanations.a: Coherence time is inversely proportional to Doppler spread, which increases with velocity. So doubling velocity halves coherence time.
explanations.b: Correct. Coherence time is inversely proportional to velocity, so it gets halved.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Coherence time changes with velocity.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It can be determined from the relation with velocity.

questions.question: If the velocity of the user was halved, what would the effect be on the PSD plot?

answers.a: The plot would get narrower and taller
answers.b: The plot would get wider and shorter
answers.c: Both may happen; but the overall shape will not change

explanations.a: Correct. Lower velocity means smaller Doppler spread, which narrows the spectrum and increases the peak.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This describes an increase in velocity.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The shape changes as Doppler spread changes.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It can be determined based on Doppler spread.

questions.question: What happens if we increase the value of α?

answers.c: Bit error rate of communication will increase

explanations.a: Incorrect. Increasing α typically leads to faster channel variations, reducing coherence time.
explanations.b: Correct. A higher α means higher Doppler, so lower coherence time.
explanations.c: Incorrect in this context. BER may change but isn't the primary effect of α.
explanations.d: Incorrect. There is a direct effect on coherence time.
